Topic.Title: Technical Analysis on AMZN

Message.Msg: Hmmm, well there is a mini momentum run here and that's what you are seeing. For the most part, technical analysis is pure BS. I won't get into explaining why. It's only valuable from time to time, and over a very short time period -- minutes really -- and is a little different than pure momentum which this stock just caught. If AMZN jumps a few more buck Monday AM then I will call a top there for sure and short it. Recent buyers will panic out when a dip emerges out of the woodwork -- guaranteed. This is not technical analysis, it is behavioral analysis. People who get caught up lose sight of the fear associated with profit protection. Mini momentum turns to mini panic in a heartbeat when the fundamentals are not there.

Message.Msg: Thanks for posting that. that article touches on two "myths" that I mentioned lately as earnings have come down: that investing buildouts should signficantly affect earnings: they shouldn't as they are capitalized items to the balance sheet that are depreciated over time. the gross margin increase story is a joke: because they are increasing fufillment,marketing, admin costs which can be defined as cost of good sold in many cases: it's a matter of what line item the new FASB standard let them put the costs. a complete joke. All doesn't matter right now as you've see two huge gapup celebrations the last two earnings on making 17 cents/shr total : that has been worth taking the stock from 196 to 237 and change so far: so on making about $100 million to the bottom line the last two qtrs , Jeff Bezos has increased his shareholder holding wealth alone by $3.7 billion in value in his holdings of about 19 % of AMZN.com. Not a bad gain in your wealth for making such little money based off two shaky assumptions above. No wonder the US is tunred off by the stock market. This Country isn't investing in the future, it's perpetuating scams today on faulty future assumptions. Bernanke should be vilified as well as his money is being used once again to perpetuate these kind scams like the housing bubble and tech bubble before. These scams are reaching new heights when you are running money into triple multiple stocks with crooked numbers in front of that first multiple now , huge market cap stocks , with little earnings: that's when the scam has reached bubble proportions. Where it ends and how, will be interesting. Bernanke is an idiot for using easy money again , leveraging up the Fed balance sheet to use that money for this stuff. Same crap happening again.

Topic.Title: Reasoning behind the gross margin increase

Message.Msg: I don't understand the rush to build out all these warehouses/fulfillment centers to save on shipping costs. These centers are very expensive to maintain and run. They will only save money on shipping if these centers run at 100% capacity. At 85-90% capacity, their shipping costs would be equal to the ones they are paying right now. If capacity falls below 85% (since the cost of maintenance and operation is fixed)their shipping costs actually increase over the current ones. So during the 3 months, during the holiday season, they will be saving on shipping costs. The rest of the year, they will be paying current to higher shipping costs then they do now. If the economy slows down and/or competition from other online retailers takes a bite out of AMZN's sales, then these centers are going to become a major liability.

Topic.Title: Seeking ALpha guy has uncovered a buy and squeeze/cancel trade scam in AMZN

Message.Msg: Any doubt that yesterdays price action came about because of a major short squeeze? Shorts have been punished the whole week by EU and the general market. Everyone and their mother margined out their accounts to short AMZN because everyone knew that their earnings would stink. This was the big play for shorts to recover their losses. It just took a few big players to hold the stock up and take it a little higher to cause the shorts to panic. With the market up 200pts, margin calls for shorts were calling. Margin calls need to be met by Fridays close. Shorts were forced to cover at any cost to cover their margin calls, hence the 8% gain in AMZN on crappy earnings. Some big players came out with some major $$$ out of this and probably a huge short position into next week.

Topic.Title: Reasoning behind the gross margin increase

Message.Msg: It's a scam. Period. There ARE costs associated with those revenues, but they are not being included in the proper place on the P&L. This is fraud. Plain and simple. Amazon is a great company. But what they are doing with the stock is an outright fraud with the full knowledge and assistance of Wall St. I have no position currently, I just trade it, but the truth is obvious about this company. It's worth $70.

Topic.Title: Reasoning behind the gross margin increase

Message.Msg: "I wonder how and why the guidance is completely ignored by analysts? " That's the part that baffles me. At best, if you're a true believer in the Amazon growth story, you might defend the share price pre-Q2 report, arguing that nothing has changed as long as revenues are growing. But why is it worth more now than before the report?

Topic.Title: Reasoning behind the gross margin increase

Message.Msg: I don't believe that the primary reason for building new fulfillment centers is to be closer to their clients. If your volumes increase by 30% annually, you have to increase your warehouse space by approximately that much in order to store and process everything. And it might have to be even more if new orders are coming from things that are more voluminous per dollar of revenue than the historic product--i.e. diapers instead of DVD's. Of course, if you are selling cereal, dog food and diapers, you might well want to have it in warehouses near the customers.

Topic.Title: Best Option Strategy (in my opinion)

Message.Msg: Yikes. My account equity is a little lower today than it was on Thursday. Glad I at least sold some puts against my long put positions. Now just have to keep selling OTM puts (weeklies or monthlies) until the price heads down again, which it will. I actually bought a couple deep ITM calls Friday AM and sold some OTM weekly calls (Aug 3) against them to hedge the short positions. That helped partially offset the losses on the October 300 puts as the price kept going up on Friday (I am long more puts than calls). I hate to take long positions on AMZN, but every now and then it feels like the right defensive thing to do. So hopefully the price will stay about where it is for a week and then head down again.
